tn.text: This is the next part of the story. Zacchaeus is introduced to the story. Verse 1 gives background information about Jesus' travels. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: Behold, there was a man there
tn.text: The word "behold" alerts us to a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this. AT: "There was a man who was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

tn.ref: He was a chief tax collector and was rich
tn.text: This is background information about Zacchaeus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"Zacchaeus was trying"

tn.ref: because he was small in height
tn.text: "because he was short"
"a sycamore fig tree." It produces small round fruit about 2.5 centimeters across. AT: "a fig tree" or "a tree"
"the tree" or "where Zacchaeus was"
"So Zacchaeus hurried"
The Jews hated the tax collectors and did not think any good person should associate with them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: He has gone in to visit a man who is a sinner
tn.text: "Jesus has gone into the house of a sinner to visit him"
"an obvious sinner" or "a real sinner" (UDB)
This refers to Jesus.
"return to them four times as much as I took from them"

tn.ref: salvation has come to this house
tn.text: It was understood that salvation comes from God. AT: "God has saved this household" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "house" here refers to the people living in the house or the family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"this man too" or "Zacchaeus also"
Possible meanings are 1) "descendant of Abraham" and 2) "person who has faith as Abraham did."
Jesus is speaking about himself. AT: "I, the Son of Man"
"the people who have wandered away from God" or "those who by sinning have wandered away from God"

Jesus begins to tell a parable to the crowd. Verse 11 gives background information about why Jesus tells the parable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: that the kingdom of God was about to appear immediately
tn.text: The Jews believed that the Messiah would establish the kingdom as soon as he came to Jerusalem. AT: "that Jesus would immediately begin to rule over God's kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"A certain man who was a member of the ruling class" or "A certain man from an important family"

tn.ref: to receive for himself a kingdom
tn.text: This is the image of a lesser king going to a greater king. The greater king would give the lesser king the right and authority to rule over his own country. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"The nobleman called." It may be helpful to state that the man did this before he left to receive his kingdom. AT: "Before he left, he called"
"gave each of them one mina"

A mina is 600 grams. Each mina was worth about what someone would be paid in four months. AT: "ten valuable coins" or "a large amount of money" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"Trade with this money" or "Use this money in order to earn more"
"the people of his country"
"a group of people to represent them" or "several messengers"
This phrase is used here to mark an important event in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
"after he had become king"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "to come to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"how much money they had earned"
"The first servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"came before the nobleman"

tn.ref: your mina has made ten minas more
tn.text: It is implied that the servant was the one who caused the profit. AT: "I used your mina to make a profit of ten more minas" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

A mina is 600 grams. Each mina was worth about what someone would be paid in four months. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:19:13|19:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])
"You have done well." Your language may have a phrase that an employer would use to show approval, such as "Good job."
This refers to the one mina, which the nobleman apparently did not consider to be a lot of money.
"The second servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])

tn.ref: Your mina, lord, has made five minas
tn.text: It is implied that the servant was the one who caused the profit. AT: "Lord, I used your mina to make a profit of five more minas" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

A mina is 600 grams. Each mina was worth about what someone would be paid in four months. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:19:13|19:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])

tn.ref: You take charge over five cities
tn.text: "You will have authority over five cities"
"another servant came"

A mina is 600 grams. Each mina was worth about what someone would be paid in four months. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:19:13|19:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])
"wrapped in a cloth and stored away"
"a stern man" or "a man who expects a lot from his servants"

tn.ref: You take up that which you did not lay down
tn.text: It was a proverb describing a greedy person. AT: "You take out what you did not put in" or "You take what is not yours" (See: [[:en:obe:other:proverb]])

tn.ref: reap that which you did not sow
tn.text: "reap what you did not plant." The servant was comparing his master to a farmer who takes food that someone else planted. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
His "words" refer to all that he had said. AT: "Based on what you have said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: that I am a severe man, taking up
tn.text: The nobleman was repeating what the servant had said about him. He was not saying that it was true.
"a harsh man"

tn.ref: why did you not put my money ... interest?
tn.text: The nobleman uses a question to rebuke the wicked servant. AT: "you should have put my money ... interest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: put my money in the bank
tn.text: "lent my money to a bank." Cultures that do not have banks might translate it as "let someone borrow my money."
A bank is a business that safely holds money for people. Banks lend that money to others for a profit. Therefore it pays an extra amount, or interest, to the people who keep their money in the bank.

tn.ref: I would have collected it with interest
tn.text: "I could have collected that amount plus the interest it would have earned" (UDB) or "I would have gained a profit from it"
Interest is money that a bank pays people who put their money in the bank.
The nobleman had become king. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:19:11|19:12]].
"the people who were standing near them"

A mina is 600 grams. Each mina was worth about what someone would be paid in four months. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:19:13|19:13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])
"he already has ten minas!"
This was the king speaking. Some translators may want to start this verse with "And the king replied, 'I say to you'" or "But the king said 'I tell you this'" (UDB).

It is implied that what he has is the money he earned by using his mina faithfully. AT: "everyone who uses well what he has been given" or "everyone who uses well what I have given him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will give him more" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

It is implied that the reason he does not have money is because he did not use his mina faithfully. AT: "from the person who does not use well what I have given him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will take away from him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Since the enemies were not right there, some languages would say "those enemies of mine."
This is the end of the part of the story about Zacchaeus. This verse tells us what Jesus did after this part of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])

tn.ref: When he had said these things
tn.text: "When Jesus had said these things"
Jerusalem was higher than Jericho, so it was normal for Israelites to speak of going up to Jerusalem.
This is the next part of the story. Jesus approaches Jerusalem.

This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
The word "he" refers to Jesus. His disciples were also traveling with him.
Bethphage was a village on the Mount of Olives, which is across the Kidron Valley from Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the hill that is called Olivet
tn.text: "the hill that is called the Mount of Olives" or "the hill that is called "Olive Tree Mountain"
"a young donkey" or "a young riding animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "that no one has ever ridden" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: If any one asks you ... need of it
tn.text: Jesus tells the disciples how to answer a question that has not yet been asked. However, people in the village will soon ask the question. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "The two disciples that Jesus sent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the owners of the colt"

tn.ref: Why are you untying ... Lord has need of it
tn.text: This is the question and answer that Jesus predicted in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:19:29|19:31]] and should be translated the same as in that verse.

tn.ref: threw their cloaks upon the colt
tn.text: "put their robes on the young donkey." Cloaks are outer robes.
"helped Jesus get up on and ride on the colt"
"people spread their cloaks." This is a sign of giving honor to someone. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"As Jesus was going near." Jesus' disciples were traveling with him.

tn.ref: where the Mount of Olives descends
tn.text: "where the road goes down from the Mount of Olives"

tn.ref: mighty works which they had seen
tn.text: "great things they had seen Jesus do"
They were saying this about Jesus.

tn.ref: in the name of the Lord
tn.text: Here "name" refers to power and authority. Also, "Lord" refers to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"May there be peace in heaven." They are expressing what they want to happen.
"highest" refers to heaven, where God lives. AT: "let everyone give glory to God in the highest heaven" or "let everyone praise God the Highest One"
"in the large crowd"
"tell your disciples to stop doing these things"
Jesus said this to emphasize what he would say next.

tn.ref: if these were silent ... cry out
tn.text: This is a hypothetical situation. Some translators may need to make it clear what Jesus was implying when he said this: "no, I will not rebuke them, for if these people were to be silent ... cry out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the stones would call out praises"
This refers to Jerusalem.
The word "it" refers to the city of Jerusalem, but it represents the people who lived in that city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: If only you had known ... bring you peace
tn.text: Jesus expressed his sadness that the people of Jerusalem had missed the opportunity to be at peace with God.

The word "you" is singular because Jesus was speaking to the city. But if this would be unnatural in your language, you could use a plural form of "you" to refer to the people of the city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: they are hidden from your eyes
tn.text: "your eyes" refer to the ability to see. This can be stated in active form. AT: "you can no longer see them" or "you are unable to know it" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus continues speaking.
What follows is the reason for Jesus' sadness.

tn.ref: the days will come upon you
tn.text: This indicates that they would experience difficult times. Some languages do not talk about time coming. AT: "in the future these things will happen to you" or "soon you will endure troublesome times"

The word "you" is singular because Jesus was speaking to the city. But if this would be unnatural in your language, you could use a plural form of "you" to refer to the people of the city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This refers to a wall to keep the people from getting out of the city.

tn.ref: They will strike you down to the ground
tn.text: Since Jesus was speaking to the city, this refers to the walls and buildings of the city. AT: "They will destroy your walls" or "They will destroy your city"
This refers to the people who lived in the city. AT: "they will kill you people in the city"

tn.ref: They will not leave one stone upon another
tn.text: "They will not leave any of the stones in place." This is a hyperbole to express how completely the enemies would destroy the city which was built of stones. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"you did not acknowledge"
This is the next event in this part of the story. Jesus enters the temple in Jerusalem.
It may be helpful to state that he entered Jerusalem first, where the temple was located. AT: "Jesus entered Jerusalem and then went to the temple courtyard"
Only priests were allowed to enter the temple building. AT: "went into the temple courtyard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"throw out" or "force out"
This is a quotation from Isaiah. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The scriptures say" or "A prophet wrote these words in the scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "My" refers to God and "house" refers to the temple.
"a place where people pray to me"
Jesus speaks of the temple as if it was a place where thieves come together. AT: "a place where thieves hide" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is the end of this part of the story. These verses tell about on-going action that continues after the main part of the story ends. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])
"in the temple courtyard" or "at the temple"
"were paying close attention to what Jesus was saying"
